header: The CPAN PR challenge is gathering heat as patches begin to appear and blog entries to surface. Catalyst sees another release, the plans for the new Test-Simple are going forward, and there is even some hopeful movements on the Perl6 front. There is no way to know if it's going to be indicative of the full year, but January sure is busy. Enjoy! ~ `/anick

entries.text: The old London Perl Jobs mailing list is going down. Dave Cross, however, has set  up a replacement, ready to take on the torch.
entries.title: London Perl Jobs Mailing List

entries.text: Ovid needs you! He's crafting a Perl 6 presentation, and as a comparative exercise, he needs to have implementations of the classic Point class written in different languages.
entries.author: curtis_ovid_poe
entries.title: Can you provide an x/y Point class in other languages?
Test-Simple, Test-More, and Test-Builder. What is breaking? Should I be scared?
entries.author: chad_granum
entries.text: So there is this new release of Test-Simple coming down the pipe. Considering that this is a linchpin modules of the Perl testing ecosystem, what exactly does it entail?

entries.title: MetaCPAN Welcomes Panopta as a Sponsor
entries.text: The CPAN web portals, search.cpan.org and metacpan, are incredibly important for our day-to-day work, and it's easy to forget that their continued existence is usually fueled by the unrelentless dedication of a few  volunteers and a budget that would make shoe strings seem opulent. In that optic, a new sponsor is always reason to celebrate. Huzzah for Panopta!
entries.author: olaf_alders

chapters.title: Perl Maven Pro
chapters.header: The Perl Maven Pro subscribers receive two new articles and screencasts every week. The last week these were the two screencasts:

entries.title: Serializers for Perl: when to use what
entries.text: YAML, JSON, Serial, so many serializers to choose from... Aristotle offers a brief overview of the serializing landscape, and provide guidance on when to use the different players in the field.
entries.author: aristotle_pagaltzis

entries.title: Preliminary Task List for the next Perl Catalyst Development Cycle "Australorp"
entries.author: john_napiorkowski
entries.text: A new release done and shipped. But no rest for the wicked: the next development cycle already starts for Catalyst. John shares with us its battleplan.

entries.title: Keeping Perl Classy
entries.text: Rose interviewed haarg on Perl in general, and its OO aspect in particular.
Contributing to a CPAN module is more than a fork and a pull request. As he attacks his first PR mission, Nitish walks us through the finer details of submitting a change to a Perl distribution.
entries.title: How to make your first contribution to CPAN - the first steps

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: For the participants of the CPAN PR challenge, Neil reviews what can be  done with the distribution that lands in your laps.
entries.title: What to do with a CPAN distribution
Always do pull requests in branches
entries.text: Neil discusses the etiquette (and good sense) of  making small, well-isolated, easy to manage branches when submitting pull requests.
entries.author: neil_bowers

entries.title: CPAN Pull Request Challenge for January: DateTime::Format::Epoch
entries.text: Michiel Beijen got assigned DateTime::Format::Epoch for January. How did he improve on that elder module? By adding NTP support!

entries.title: Downloading Criminal podcast episodes
entries.author: sawyer_x
entries.text: No, Sawyer is not going full black-hat on us. He's merely going through the  exercise of writing a script that downloads all the episodes of this new podcast he found.
Want to match delimited text, but Text::Balanced and Regexp::Common aren't good enough for the job? Be happy, for there is a new Marpa-based solution in town.
entries.author: ron_savage
entries.title: Fancy Matching of Delimited Text
Awesome Perl
entries.text: Not an article, but rather a list of want the curator considers  awesome Perl libraries and frameworks.

entries.title: Getting Choosy
entries.author: mark_fowler
entries.text: For the interactive scripts running on MacOS, a new release of Mac::Choose is out, now offering additional drop-down shininess.

entries.author: dave_jacoby
entries.text: Dave saw something neat in Ramda.js, and checked out how easy it'd be to port the idea in Perl-space.
entries.title: A Higher Order Idea stolen from Ramda.js

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: Yanick ventured in his laboratory and spent a few hours stitching together a creature made of InfluxDB, Grafana and Bread::Board.
entries.title: The Hills Have Multi-Faceted Eyes
Metaprogramming HTML::FormHandler
entries.author: thomas_klausner
entries.text: Web forms are a pain. Domm tries to  reduce the overall amount of tedium  via an intake of meta-programming. Smart move, or terrible mistake? You be the judge.
Mojolicious comes with a lot of snazzy tools to retrieve and manipulate web content. brian demonstrates.
entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.title: Extracting from HTML with Mojo::DOM

entries.text: Makoto reports on the Perl foundation grants for December. Inline::C/CPP as well as a new Perl::Lint are two improvements that should make people happy.
entries.author: makoto_nozaki
entries.title: Grant Reports for December
2015.01 Get ready to Party!
entries.text: Will 2015 be the year Christmas will come? It's way too early to say -- first, let's see about Easters -- but things are nonetheless stirring in the Perl6 world.

entries.title: Timestamp and elapsed time in Perl 6
entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Perl 6 has two separate functions fetching the time since the epoch and they return different results. As of today they are 35 seconds apart.

entries.title: CPAN great modules released last week
How to get the size of a file in Perl
entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Using -s is simple, but looks strange for people not yet familiar with it. There are other, more readable ways to fetch the size of a file.

subject: Pull, Request and Release!
